subject: Leadership
title: The Slippery Slope
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Slippery Slope usable.

hook.text: Nobody wakes up planning to commit fraud. It starts with a small shortcut, then another, then another.

buildup.text: Gino and Bazerman: gradual ethical erosion is harder to detect than sudden violations. The slope is invisible.

discovery.text: Each small compromise adjusts the internal baseline. What felt wrong last month feels normal now. The line moves.

twist.text: Organizations enable slopes through pressure to perform. If targets demand unethical speed, people cut ethical corners.

climax.text: Watch for normalizing language: 'everyone does it' or 'it's just this once.' Those are early warnings of the slope.

punchline.text: Big scandals always start with small exceptions.

quiz.question: Why is gradual ethical erosion especially dangerous?
options: Each compromise adjusts the baseline so the decline feels normal
It only happens in large corporations
